Definition: Baseline definition of economic connectedness: two times the share of high-SES friends within three birth cohorts among low-SES individuals, averaged over all low-SES individuals in the college. See equations (1), (2), and (3) of Chetty et al. (2022a) for a formal definition.

Economic connectedness with parental SES: two times the share
of high-parental-SES friends (who attended the same school within
three birth cohorts of the individual) among low-parental-SES individuals, averaged over all low-parental-SES individuals at the college.

Economic connectedness for high-SES individuals: two times the
share of high-SES friends within three birth cohorts among high-SES
individuals, averaged over all high-SES individuals in the college

Economic connectedness for high-parental-SES individuals using
parental SES: two times the share of high-parental-SES friends (who
attended the same school within three birth cohorts of the individual) among high-parental-SES individuals, averaged over all highparental-SES individuals in the college

Average net price for $0-$30,000 family income (public institutions)
column4: The average annual total cost of attendance (CostT4_A, CostT4_P), including tuition and fees, books and supplies, and living expenses, minus the average grant/scholarship aid, by detailed income category. It is calculated for all full-time, first-time, degree/certificate-seeking undergraduates who receive Title IV aid. It is included in the IPEDS Student Financial Aid component. Separate metrics are calculated for public institutions and private institutions for each of the following five income categories: $0-$30,000; $30,001-$48,000; $48,001-$75,000; $75,001-$110,000; $110,001 or more. For public institutions, this metric is limited to full-time, first-time, degree/certificate-seeking undergraduates who pay in-state tuition and receive Title IV aid. For private institutions, it includes all full-time, first-time, degree/certificate-seeking undergraduates who receive Title IV aid. For academic-year institutions, net price represents an average of all programs and includes only full-time, first-time, degree/certificate-seeking undergraduates who first enrolled in the fall term. For non-academic-year institutions (program or continuous enrollment), net price represents the program with the largest enrollment at the institution and it includes full-time, first-time, degree/certificate-seeking undergraduates who first enrolled at any time during the academic year. For programs less than 1 year in length (see LPROGRAM), this represents the net price for the full program. The total cost of attendance depends on whether full-time, first-time, degree/certificate-seeking undergraduates live on campus, off campus (not with family), or off campus (with family). Income categories are calculated from the income values used by the institution to calculate financial aid eligibility. For a dependent student, this includes the student's and the parents' income. For an independent student, this includes the s2tudent's adjusted gross income and, if the student is married, the spouse's income. This metric is not available prior to the 2009-10 academic year.
